ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] I/O exception (java.net.ConnectException) caught when processing request

From: Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...>
Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] I/O exception (java.net.ConnectException) caught
 when processing request
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=yYqEm9-si11dePaIqw4a1L9lujIx_i-fUVjHvhid2aA7
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

This is quite normal when the remote site is not accepting inbound TCP 
connections. (Though, with our usual logging-level setup, these INFO 
messages aren't logged; instead such failures only are logged in 
local-errors.log.)

If the attempts to connect fail the number of times specified by the 
'max-retries' setting, Heritrix gives up on that URI, and moves to the 
next URI in the same queue (which is also likely to fail, if it's on the 
same non-responsive host). The '-2' status code is our code for 'failed 
all/last connects'.

The default 'max-retries' value is 30; together with the 'retry-delay' 
of 900 seconds, this means a site has to be non-responsive for hours 
before Heritrix gives up on a URI. Given that networks and sites 
sometimes have transient outages, we thought this was a reasonable default.

It appears you've set 'max-retries' to 3 (as evidenced by the '3t' 
notation on your crawl.log lines). That means there's little margin for 
Heritrix to overlook transient problems. Also, the normal process of 
deferring the first URI on a host first to get the DNS info, then to get 
the robots info, consumes 2 retries. So a 'max-retries' as low as 3 
risks giving up on the first URI on a host after a single real connect 
failure. I recommend a larger value.

- Gordon @ IA
